(1) Insufficiency of form in contractS. We shall see that in Roman law agreements were actionable only if they were clothed in a definite form, or belonged to one or other of certain classes specially favoured'; exactly as in English law no promise is legally binding unless made either under seal or for valuable consideration. Agreements which neither belonged to the favoured classes, nor were expressed in the proper form, were nuda pacta, and unactionable, although (according to Savigny and many other writers) they gave rise to a natural obliga- tion enforceable in other ways. This is inserted in particular from Dig. 2. 14. 7. 4 ‘igitur nuda pactio obligationem non parit, sed parit exceptionem,’ ib. r. pr. ‘ huius edicti aequitas naturalis est: quid enim tam congruum fidei humanae, quam ea, quae inter eos placu- erunt, servari: Dig. 46. 3. 5. 2 ⁶ . . . puta, quaedam earum [usurarum] ex stipulatione, quaedam ex pacto naturaliter debebantur: . . . et sicut ex pacti conventione datae repeti non possunt ς’· cf. Dig. ib. 95. 4·. Most directly they are sup- ported by Dig. 45. 1. 1. 2 ‘ si quis ita interroget, dabis? responderit, , quidni? et is utique in ea causa est, ut obligetur. Contra si sine verbis adnuisset, non tanturn autem civiliter, sed nec naturaliter obli- gatur, qui ita adnuit: et ideo recte dictum est, non obligari pro eo nec fideiussorem quidem.'
